item.title: How to use @autoclosure in Swift to improve performance
item.description: An autoclosure is a Swift closure that is automatically created to wrap an expression passed as a function argument. In this post, Antoine Van Der Lee demonstrates how we can use autoclosures and provides examples of Swift APIs which use this feature.

item.title: @autoclosure what, why and when
item.description: In this short post, Pavel Gnatyuk explains what the Swift autoclosure attribute is, why it’s useful, and when we can use it.

item.title: Replacing @autoclosure in Swift
item.description: Benjamin Herzog takes inspiration from Scala and looks at how we might replace the use of @autoclosure in Swift. It’s an interesting idea, and even if you don’t agree it still provides food for thought.

item.title: Using @autoclosure when designing Swift APIs
item.description: The @autoclosure attribute enables us to define function arguments which can be expressed as a simple expression at the call site, but which are then automatically wrapped in a closure. This has the benefit of delaying execution, as with an explicit closure, while also reducing the verbosity of our code. In this post John Sundell provides 3 quick examples of using @autoclosure when designing our APIs. While reading this it's also worth keeping in mind a note from Apple's official Swift programming guide which points out that overusing autoclosures can make our code hard to understand. Use wisely.
